title: 106_hr4685
content: The "Campaign Finance Improvement Act of 2000" expands reporting requirements for certain contributions. The "Campaign Finance Improvement Act of 2000" expands reporting requirements for political committees receiving contributions of $200 or more, mandating notification to the Commission within 10 days of receipt. Additionally, it includes details such as the contributor's identification, date of receipt, amount of contribution, and candidate information. This reporting is in addition to all other required reports under the Act. The Act (2 U.S.C. 434(a)(6)(A)) is amended to change the reporting requirements for political committees. The amendment reduces the reporting threshold from $1,000 to $200 and extends the reporting deadline from the 20th day to the 90th day. The Act is amended to change reporting requirements for political committees, reducing the threshold to $200 and extending the deadline to the 90th day. Section 3 requires a majority of contributions accepted by congressional candidates to come from in-state residents. The Federal Election Campaign Act is amended to require that at least 50% of contributions accepted by candidates for Senate or House elections come from in-state individual residents. If a candidate spends over $250,000 of personal funds, this requirement does not apply to their opponents. The Federal Election Campaign Act is amended to allocate contributions from political committees, with 50% from in-state individual residents and 50% from others. Reporting requirements for candidate committees are also specified in the amendment. The Federal Election Campaign Act amendment requires reporting of contributions received by candidate committees before and after an election. Principal campaign committees must notify the Commission of the first expenditure of personal funds. The Federal Election Campaign Act amendment mandates reporting contributions exceeding $250,000. Candidates violating contribution limits face fines up to 200 percent of the excess amount. Candidates violating contribution limits face fines up to 200 percent of the excess amount, with interest assessed on unpaid fines after 30 days. SEC. 4 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act regarding the identification of contributors. SEC. 5 lowers the threshold for cash contributions from $100 to $20. SEC. 6 addresses contributions by dependents not of voting age. Section 315(a) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include provisions for contributions made by dependent minors. Such contributions will be treated as if made by the dependent's parent or parents, depending on the situation. A dependent minor is defined as an individual who is dependent on another person and has not reached the age of majority at the time of making the contribution. Dependent minors making contributions must not have reached the legal voting age in their state at the time of the contribution. SEC. 7 prohibits non-citizen individuals from contributing to federal elections. SEC. 8 outlines disclosure requirements for certain soft money expenditures of political parties. Transfers of funds by national political parties are amended to include all funds transferred to state or local political parties. State political parties must disclose information reported under state law. The amendment requires state political parties to file a copy of their disbursement report with the Commission if they are required to submit it to a state or local government entity under state or local law. SEC. 9 prohibits the involuntary assessment of employee funds for political activities. SEC. 9 prohibits national banks, corporations, and labor organizations from collecting dues or fees for political activities without individual authorization. The amendment prohibits entities from collecting dues for political activities without individual authorization, defining political activity as influencing elections or legislation. Authorization remains in effect until revoked, with individuals able to revoke at any time. Effective date applies to amounts collected after the amendment. The amendment prohibits entities from collecting dues for political activities without individual authorization, defining political activity as influencing elections or legislation. Authorization remains in effect until revoked, with individuals able to revoke at any time. Effective date applies to amounts collected or assessed on or after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 10 prohibits authorized committees of candidates from accepting contributions from other candidates' committees, with exceptions for transfers within the same candidate's committees. SEC. 11 mandates the FEC to provide software for electronic filing. SEC. 11 mandates the FEC to obtain computer software through competitive bidding for electronic filing of designations, statements, and reports under the Act. SEC. 12 states that the amendments apply to elections and transactions after December 31, 2000.
